pageContext.description:
A copper alloy, flanged, Flat Axehead, dating from the Arreton phase of the Middle Bronze Age, about 1700 - 1500 BC. It has flanged parallel sides, the butt end is squared off, with rounded corners, and there is a crescent shaped blade with upturned corners. There is a very shallow stop ridge, now difficult to discern. In side elevation the septum and flanges are in the form of a very slender oval and the outer sides of the flanges are decorated with a moulded, diagonal, ropework pattern that is a characteristic of the Arreton phase. Other than some abrasion around the butt end and some surface chips on one side of the septum and one flange, the axe is in very good condition with a smooth, dark green patina. It is 128.7mm long, 72.3mm wide and 17.2mm thick. It weighs 414gm.



Other axeheads of this type are recorded on the database: see for example references LANCUM-19A734 and LANCUM-EFEAC0. Axes of this type are also illustrated in Megaw and Simpson, 1981, Introduction to British Prehistory, figure 2.29, numbers 5 and 6
